loans.name: Shola

texts.en:
This is 57-year-old Shola. He is married and has 4 children ages 34, 30, 29, and 26. 

In 2001, Shola established his spare parts business. He began his business just to enable him to adequately cater to his family. His business is his only source of survival. Working 7 days a week and 13 hours a day, he earns about 1,600,000 SLL every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. Shola has already received and successfully repaid a loan and now requires a new loan in order to buy engine oil, oil filter gasket maker, brake pads and batteries. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 350,000 SLL. 

In the future, Shola plans to establish a larger spare parts shop, to embark on international business and to own a house. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is married. He has four children. All his children go to school. 

He has been a rice farmer for two years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy seeds, pesticides and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy seeds, pesticides and support labor costs for his rice production.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is single. He has been a rice farmer for 10 years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest of rice production. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and support labor costs in rice production.

loans.name: Nuevo Porvenir 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Mercedes is one of the members of the Nuevo Progress (New Progress Group) 3 & 4. The group is made up of ten businesswomen who live in the northeast of the capital city, Santo Domingo, and they run a variety of businesses: sales, cosmetics, beauty salons, shoe sales, fruit and vegetables sales, and others. They sell their wares in their community and in other nearby areas. Every day these businesswomen work to improve their quality of life.

Mercedes is receiving her eighth loan from Esperanza Internacional (Hope International). She will use the loan to invest in her business, selling fruits and vegetables. She sells her goods wholesale and to individuals. She will purchase plantains, yucca, fruits, and vegetables with the loan.

Mercedes hopes to have an established business, which will allow her to support her family and make changes in her life, like having a good home and stable economic situation. She is excited to receive your support; your support will help them reach their dreams.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Jeneba

texts.en: This is 46-year-old Jeneba. She is married and has four children, ages 23, 18,16 and 13 years old. In 1996, Jeneba established her imported food sales business. She began her business just to enable her contribution to the running of the home, and that is major source of survival. Working seven days a week and one hour a day, she earns about Le 1,350,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Jeneba has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now requires a new loan in order to  buy vegetables oil, onions, Irish potato, jumbo Maggie, sugar and tomatoes. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 210,000. In the future, Jeneba plans to develop her business into a shop, give quality education to her children and to own a house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy vegetables oil, onions, Irish potato, jumbo Maggie, sugar and tomatoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food for resale.

loans.name: Diogene

texts.en:
Diogene has one child, age 5. 

He has been a rice farmer for five years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy seeds, pesticides and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds, pesticides and support labor costs for the rice production.

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is married. He has three children. All of them go to school.

He has been a rice farmer for four years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy seeds, pesticides and support labor costs to get the best harvest and upgrade his rice production. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output and make more savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To cover labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is married. He has been a rice farmer for eight years. 

He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy seeds, pesticides and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay for seeds, pesticides and support labor costs for his rice production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food for resale.

loans.name: Yatta

texts.en: This is 40-year-old Yatta. She is married and has four children, ages 21, 16, 10 and 4 years old. She has one additional dependent who lives with her for schooling.  In 2008, Yatta established her textile and jewelry sales business. She began her business just to enable her take care of her home in the absence of her husband, and that is her only source of livelihood. Working six days a week and ten hours a day, she earns about Le 900,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Yatta requires a loan in order to buy necklaces, watches, earrings and shoes. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000. In the future, Yatta plans to transform her table into a shop, to own a house and to send her children to a post-secondary school. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy necklaces, watches, earrings and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: This is 38-year-old Fatmata. She is married and has two children, ages 12 and 15 years old. She has two additional dependents, who live with her because they are in school. In 2002, Fatmata established her shoe sales business. She began her business to enable her to care for herself and her dependents, and the business is her only source of livelihood at the moment. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, she earns about Le 800,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Fatmata requires a loan in order to buy plastic slippers. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000. In the future, Fatmata plans to develop her plot of land in Bo, to develop her business into a shop and to give her children a quality education. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy plastic shoes for resale.

loans.name: Santa

texts.en:
Santa is one of our associates from the Hato Mayor Branch, a rural town whose economy depends on agriculture. She has been running a grocery store for about eight years, which she started with her first loan in Esperanza Internacional, and after nine loans, her business has been improving and expanding for more clients and products. For the grocery store, she will buy products like rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, canned food, and many other goods.

Santa lives with one of her two children and her long term partner in their simple structure home. She said that her most difficult challenge is to build her house in a concrete block structure to be safer and in better condition. She enjoys working in her business. She is very excited to be receiving her tenth loan from Esperanza Internacional. She plans to save the profits for future investments and needs. She thanks you all for your support!

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, canned food, and many other goods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy parts for refrigerators, and to buy goods for a grocery store.

loans.name: Progresando En Valores 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Ysabel is the coordinator of her group, Progresando en Valores 1, 2 & 3 (Progress in Values). Her group is located in Samana, a lush, rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry. She makes her home in a simple structure with her long-term partner and four children. She says that her most difficult challenge is to finish building her house. She has been building her home little by little, adding rooms and finishing last details. In the meantime, she continues to enjoy sewing.

Ysabel is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza. She has had her business, which she started with some savings, for almost four years. She plans to use this loan to increase her inventory by buying men's and women's clothes. She will use the profits to continue building her house. Her dreams are to work hard and move her business forward, and with the help of God, she will. She thanks all of you for your support!

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia has been working as a distributor of health products for a national company for four years. She has an office in Cusco, from which she transacts business with local sellers and businesses in Lima. Celia is requesting a loan in order to buy more merchandise such as food, nutrients, and vitamins that promote a healthy and balanced lifestyle.

Celia is 29 years old and has one child with her partner. She dreams of buying her own house and providing a better quality of life for her children. She would also like to travel and get to know other countries.

Celia is receiving an individual loan as a member of the village bank "Vallecito" in Cusco, which is located close to the Incan ruins of Macchu Picchu in the Andean mountains. The bank is in its 17th cycle with Asociación Arariwa.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise, such as health foods, nutrients, and vitamins for resale.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.es:
La socia anteriormente se dedicaba al negocio de venta de andamios metalicos pero no le fue muy bien en este negocio, ahora se esta dedicando al negocio de venta de materiales de construccion como cemento,arena,yeso y clavos,por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos,el sueño de la socia es ampliar y mejorar el negocio de venta de materiales de construccion.La socia solicita el credito para comprar cemento,arena y yeso al por mayor.

La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete  a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de acuerdo al cronograma de pagos.
texts.en:
This member used to sell metal railings but that business didn't go so well for her. Now she is selling construction materials such as cement, sand, plaster and nails. With this business, she gets her children ahead. Her dream is to expand her construction materials selling business. She is asking for the loan to buy cement, sand and plaster wholesale.

This member is grateful for the loan and promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand and plaster wholesale.

loans.name: Mahuena Sourou Group

texts.fr: MAHUENA SOUROU est un groupement composé de dix huit personnes, et dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupement, Emilienne (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 57 ans. Emilienne est  mariée à un certain Désiré. Le couple a un enfant, qui est scolarisé et à leur charge. Emilienne vit ensemble avec  son mari et son enfant. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Emilienne n'a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Emilienne vend depuis une quinzaine d'année, des condiments et du riz dans un marché du Bénin. Emilienne s’approvisionne au Bénin. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité pour être plus compétitive sur le marché, Emilienne sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupement MAHUENA SOUROU, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier crédit a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
MAHUENA SOUROU is a group of 18 people who all live in the same neighborhood.

Emilienne (who is raising her hand in the photo) is the group's representative. She is 57 years old. Emilienne is married to a man named Désiré. The couple has one child, who has received schooling and lives in their care. Emilienne lives with her husband and child. The couple covers the various household expenses together. Emilienne did not go to school.

To cover her various expenses, Emilienne has been selling condiments and rice at a market in Benin for about 15 years now. She stocks up in Benin.

Striving to grow her business in order to become more competitive on the market, Emilienne, along with the other members of MAHUENA SOUROU, is seeking a second loan from ALIDé. The first loan was correctly repaid.

loans.use: to buy condiments and bags of rice

loans.name: La Exelencia Group

texts.es: El Banco de Emprendimiento EXELENCIA esta  compuesto por 10 integrantes todas mujeres,  la presidenta del banco de emprendimiento es la Sra. Rosa  tiene 38 años esta casada  tiene 5 hijos  de las edades de 2, 5, 14, 16 y 19, cuatro de sus hijos se encuentran estudiando, todos todavía dependen de ella, la Sra. Rosa se dedica  a la  venta de comida, esta es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Rosa  utilizara  este préstamo para la compra de mesas y sillas para ampliar su negocio  y brindar mayor comodidad a sus clientes generar mas ingresos y  así de esta manera incrementar su capital de trabajo, la Sra. Rosa enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia y  utilizara los beneficios para mejorar su calidad de vida, la Sra. Rosa es una persona muy trabajadora, se siente orgullosa y feliz por su trabajo y por el apoyo que le brinda la institución.
texts.en: The EXELENCIA Entrepreneur Bank is made up of 10 members, all of them women. The bank president is Rosa. She is 38, married and has 5 children, aged 2,5,14,16 and 19. Four of her children are in school, all of them depend on her. Rosa sells food and this is her first cycle in the institution. Rosa will use this loan to buy tables and chairs to expand her business, offer her customers more comfort, generate more income and thus increase her working capital. Rosa faces challenges in her business, such as competition. She will use the profits to improve her quality of life. Rosa is a very hardworking woman. She is proud and happy with her work and for the support offered by the institution.

loans.use: to buy tables and chairs.

loans.name: Ingrid Katerine

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Circunvalación de la ciudad de Manta, cada 15 días se reúne el Banco Comunal Nuevo Proyecto. Ciudad conocida por sus hermosas playas que son muy visitadas en toda época del año por turistas nacionales y extranjeros y por  ser uno de los puertos más importantes del país y de América situado a orillas del Pacifico.

En este lugar vive la señora Ingrid, tiene 38 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos de 18 y 11 años de edad, la mayor estudia en Universidad y el menor esta en escuela. Su esposo es maestro constructor.

Ella con la finalidad de obtener sus propios ingresos hace casi 4 años y con lo poco que tenia y con la ayuda de su familia pudo adecuar un local en su casa y surtir una tienda general, la misma que poco a poco y con ayuda de los créditos ha podido ir aumentando su negocio, actualmente en su tienda tiene de todo para complacer a sus clientes ya que estos son los más importantes, allí en su local además de víveres también vende artículos de bazar y papelería y productos de Esika, (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas), trabaja todos los días todo el día, allí se entretiene y se gana la vida.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar toda clase de víveres y cosméticos de Esika. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 7 años, es la tesorera del banco y le gusta porque los créditos le ayudan mucho.
 
Sus metas son terminar sus estudios y le gustaría ser farmacéutica.
texts.en:
In the Circunvalación neighborhood of the city of Manta, the Nuevo Proyecto communal bank meets every two weeks. This city is known for its beautiful beaches that are frequented all year round by domestic and foreign tourists. It is also known for being one of the most important ports in the country and in the Americas, located on the Pacific. 

This is where Ingrid lives. She is 38 years old, married and the mother of two children, aged 18 and 11. The oldest goes to college and the youngest is in school. Her husband is a master builder. 

In order to have her own income, four years ago, with what little she had and with her family's help she was able to set up a locale in her house and stock a general store. Little by little and with the help of loans, she has been able to grow her business. Now her store has everything her customers want since they are the most important thing. In her locale, besides food products she also sells a variety of items such as paper products and Esika products (beauty items, cosmetic, perfume, and women's accessories). She works every day all day long. She stays busy there and makes her living. 

She is going to use this loan to stock her store. She will buy all types of food products and Esika cosmetics. She has been in the communal bank for 7 years. She is the bank treasurer and she likes it because the loans help her a lot.
 
Her goals are to finish her studies and she would like to be a pharmacist.

loans.use: to buy food products and Esika cosmetics.

loans.name: Xenia Roxana

texts.en:
Xenia makes a living buying and selling vegetables. She purchases lettuce, potatoes, carrots and fruit from markets in Cusco, then sends them to Puerto Maldonado for sale upon arrival. She has had this business for about one year, and is requesting a loan in order to buy more vegetables. Her dream is to eventually buy a car to transport the products, rather than relying on third-party services. 

Xenia is 20 years old and lives with her partner and one child.

Xenia is receiving an individual loan as a member of the village bank "Vallecito" in Cusco, which is located close to the Incan ruins of Macchu Picchu in the Andean mountains. The bank is in its 17th loan cycle with Asociación Arariwa.

loans.use: to buy vegetables such as lettuce, potatoes, carrots and fruit.

loans.name: Jose Alfredo

texts.en:
Jose is a 35-year-old taxi driver in the city of Cusco. He drives his own car and has been working in transport for three years. He is requesting a loan in order to replace the tires of his vehicle, and also to pay for repairs in case of accidents. His dream is to move into heavy transport and run a business carrying freight for customers. 

Jose is receiving an individual loan as a member of the village bank "Vallecito" in Cusco, which is located close to the Incan ruins of Macchu Picchu in the Andean mountains. The bank is in its 17th loan cycle with Asociación Arariwa.

loans.use: to replace his vehicle's tires and pay for repairs.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto is a contractor who works in housing construction. He is 34 years old and has two children, both in primary school. He is requesting a loan in order to make payments on a plot of land he recently purchased. He is planning to build a house for his family on the land. He looks forward to seeing his house completed, and hopes that he will continue to have a secure job in the future.

Roberto is receiving an individual loan as a member of the village bank "Vallecito" in Cusco, which is located close to the Incan ruins of Macchu Picchu in the Andean mountains. The bank is in its 17th loan cycle with Asociación Arariwa.

loans.use: to pay for land, where he will build a house.

loans.name: Mounawaratou

texts.fr:
Mounawaratou est une femme âgé(e) de 39 ans. Elle est mariée à un chauffeur et 01enfant  scolarisé de 18ans.
Mounawaratou travaille comme revendeuse de bazins et pagnes depuis 2003. Elle vend de façon ambulante et s’approvisionne à Lomé.
Mounawaratou a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des pagnes et bazins.
Dans les prochaines années, Mounawaratou voudrait faire évoluer son activité et assurer l’épanouissement de la famille.
texts.en:
Mounawaratou is a 39-year-old woman. She is married to a taxi driver and has one 18-year-old child who has received schooling.

Mounawaratou has been selling damasks and loincloths since 2003. She is an itinerant vendor, and she stocks up in Lomé.

Mounawaratou sought her first loan from WAGES in order to buy loincloths and damasks.

In the coming years, Mounawaratou would like to develop her business and ensure a bright future for her family.

loans.use: to buy loincloths and damasks

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana is 27 years old and has an 8-year-old daughter and a 5-year-old son with her partner. She runs a small restaurant in her house, where she serves lunch menus consisting of soup and a main course. She has had this business for four years. At this time, Ana would like a loan to buy a plot of land so that she can start a farm. Her dream is to see her children become professionals.

Ana is receiving an individual loan as a member of the village bank "Vallecito" in Cusco, which is located close to the Incan ruins of Macchu Picchu in the Andean mountains. The bank is in its 17th loan cycle with Asociación Arariwa.

loans.use: to buy farmland.

loans.name: 01.06.03 Đông Sơn Group

texts.en:
Lâm is applying for a loan to purchase construction equipment to do building services. She has a construction-service business.

Lâm is 55 years old and she is married with three children..

Lâm is the group leader of the 01.06.03 Đông Sơn solidarity group, which consists of eight members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with one dependent.

In 2006, Lâm joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Lâm has successfully repaid four loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. 

Lâm has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Lâm hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase construction equipment to do building services.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is from the village of Sebasi, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old, separated from her spouse and has a child. To make a living, Leonora has had a general store for eight years and earns 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month. 

In 2008, Leonora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en: Rogelio is from Gala, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. He is 38 years old, married and a father of four children. Rogelio is a farmer. He plants and harvests bananas and root crops to earn a living. He has been engaged in this business for 20 years. Each month, he earns 15,000 PHP from farming. He has requested a loan of 22,486 PHP from GDMPC to purchase seedlings and fertilizers. Rogelio joined GDMPC in 2004. In the future, Rogelio hopes to expand his banana business and gain more profit.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Arturo

texts.en:
Arturo, married, is 66 years old and lives in Tabid, Ozamiz City, Philippines.

To earn a living, Arturo is operating a general store, selling a variety of products to local community members. He has been doing this for 32 years and every month he earn 5,000 PHP from this work. He has requested a loan of 8,700 PHP to purchase new items in order to expand the products he offers.

In 2007, Arturo joined GDMPC. Arturo hopes to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase new items for his store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en: Marcelina is 48 years old and has earned a living for the last six years by selling vegetables. She has been saving money to pay for the education of her three children. She works hard and without complaint because she is committed to the welfare of her family. Now, she is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy fruits and vegetables such as peaches, cabbage, bitter melon and tomatoes. She is hoping to increase her profits in order to provide her family with an opportunity to advance in life.

loans.use: to buy fruits andvegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Eulogia

texts.en: Eulogia is from Maquilao, Tangub City. She is 58 years old. Eulogia is widowed and has 3 children. To make a living, Eulogia operates a fishing business, where she buys and sells fish to local community members. Eulogia has been in her business for 20 years and earns 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Eulogia joined GDMPC. Eulogia is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Jeneth

texts.en:
This is Jeneth, 49, resident of Baseco, Manila, Philippines. Her husband is Timoteo, a mechanic, and the father of her two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business.  She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Jeneth operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy kitchen wares & appliances from wholesalers, sell them per item for a profit. Her products are kitchen tables, water jugs, plate holders and other similar products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many products that she offers. Jeneth's regular customers are neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, Jeneth is requesting a Php 50, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Jeneth hopes to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of supplies and products needed in her business

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.es:
La socia anteriormente se dedicaba al negocio de fabricacion de ladrillos y tejas y tambien se dedicaba al negocio de crianza de animales pero no le fue muy bien,ahora se esta dedicando al negocio de venta de cereales como trigo,maiz y cebada,por medio de este negocio la socia quiere salir adelnate,el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de cereales.La socia solocita el credito para comprar trigo,cebada y maiz.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Anastasia makes bricks and roof tiles. She also raises animals but this hasn't been going well. Now she has begun selling grain, including wheat, corn, and barley. Anastasia wants to forge ahead by means of this business.

Her dream is to expand her grain-selling business. She is requesting a loan to buy wheat, barley, and corn. Anastasia is happy about the loan and is committed to compliance with her repayment schedule.

loans.use: to buy wheat, barley, and corn to sell.

loans.name: Marry

texts.en:
Marry is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Marry has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that  sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. She had this business for 3 years. She requested a loan for 10,000 PHP to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages.
Marry has been a member of HSPFI since 2012.  In the future, Marry hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of shampoo, junk foods, soap,and beverages
